title: Before 1 July 2018, will Tesla announce that it will build a factory to manufacture electric vehicles in China?
possible_answers: Yes, manufacturing without a Chinese partner
Yes, manufacturing with a Chinese partner

Robin Ren, announced Tuesday night that the company plans to build its first factory outside of the U.S. — in Shanghai. The Chinese government recently announced that it will allow foreign electric vehicle makers to fully own auto factories there. Tesla's move into China is hotly anticipated, as building some vehicles there would allow the company to avoid import tariffs. https://www.cnbc.com/2018/06/06/tesla-shareholder-meeting-elon-musk-reveals-automakers-factory-plans.html
Waiting for question about if the meeting being an announcement to be resolved...
Becoming more secure in my interpretation. The question is indeed asking about an announcement by Tesla the company, i.e. something official, and not what transpired at the shareholder meeting.
Oh well, false alarm. All eyes on https://twitter.com/ElonMusk or SEC-filing or press release.
Whatever GJO decides, I consider the question resolved and this is my final forecast on it.

Ok, I don't believe the Tesla shareholder meeting this week [1] actually provided an official announcement and therefore shouldn't resolve this question as a "yes". @amory10 Here are the quotes from the meeting that make any mentions of the China factory: Elon: "We are close to announcing something [combined battery and car factory] in China" ... "Robin, do you want to talk about that ... I mean, we don't want to make an announcement" Robin: "I didn't expect to talk about this ... We are incredibly excited to build the first Tesla Gigafactory outside of the US, in China, specifically, it's gonna be in Shanghai. We've been holding discussions with the government..." " We are going to announce all the details really soon, I won't say more" Elon: "Probably we will be announcing details on the China Gigafactory as soon as next month" I see these quotes as confirming that Tesla has *plans* to build a factory. In a sense nothing new - we've known this has been a goal for Tesla. Perhaps the only new piece of information is as a confirmation that they are getting closer. Clearly, Tesla is refraining from making official announcement (a confirmation to its shareholders) that it is indeed doing this. It may seem like I am belaboring this, and fixating on unimportant distinctions. But when you are a public company with a fiduciary responsibility to shareholders and regulated by the SEC with regard to anything that you do that might influence your stock price, then you are very careful about what you communicate to the outside world and the meaning of "announcement" takes a new level of gravity. The reason I have 20% yes is to hedge against the possibility that GJO will rule against my interpretation. [1] https://www.tesla.com/shareholdermeeting ***EDIT: if anybody wants to hear the quotes, they appear at around minute 35:00 in the video.
Hedging for whether recent news could be considered an announcement.

Tesla has been holding talks with Shanghai for over a year about building a factory in China, but of course, concerns about intellectual property rights and uncertainty over tariffs has held any deal from coming to fruition . Then in mid-April, China announced that they would remove the foreign ownership caps for manufacturing fully electric and plug-in hybrid vehicles in 2018.   https://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-autos-regulation/china-to-open-auto-market-as-trade-tensions-simmer-idUSKBN1HO0YA  Last week on a flight, I was handed a copy of The China Daily that announced a preliminary deal was in the works for a Tesla plant in a coastal Chinese city. http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/a/201805/26/WS5b08d57ea31001b82571c716.html  I think a deal will be announced at some point this year but probably not before July 1st.

Was Elon's dig at Big Oil legit or a Trumpy-style distractor? Is he stressing out?  Who knows? But announcing this to change the media talking heads focus could be possible.  Oh look a shiny new factory in China! Nah. Maybe a December release?

Tesla set up wholly-owned subsidiary in Shanghai. If none of Tesla's announcements so far have resolved the question, I'm inclined to think a big, incontrovertible announcement will not be forthcoming in the next month.
While announcement of this sort is quite likely to happen eventually, given the limited time frame the probability would be very low.

They are reorganizing again and ducking production, quality, and finance questions again.  Even if this fools the firm's investors (spoiler alert: it will), the Chinese government is not likely to want such a sketchy outfit around.  They have enough sketchy outfits of their own to deal with.

The probability of manufacturing without a Chinese partner under the current Chinese model is basically zero. Due to intellectual property right issues, global trade/logistics, and under-valued/rated economies elsewhere, I find it very unlikely that Tesla will  make an announcement involving manufacturing in China.

Based on latest comments on Q1 call.

During the Q1 earnings call, Musk said the second factory (which will be in China) will be announced "later this year /.../ maybe next quarter". Combined with the financial challenges Tesla is facing and the unresolved tariff war threats, it seems to me extremely unlikely that an announcement will come early enough for this question. Here is the transcript: "Phil LeBeau - CNBC LLC And a follow up. Given the fact that you're already packed to the gills in Fremont, when will you make a decision regarding a second manufacturing facility? Elon Reeve Musk - Tesla, Inc. So that's probably later this year. It has to be later this year. So I'm not sure of the exact time but I don't know, maybe next quarter, but not later than fourth quarter for Model Y. And then we also expect to announce the location of the Tesla Gigafactory in China soon. Phil LeBeau - CNBC LLC And will that second factory, when you announce it, will it be in North America? Or is that going to be in China? Elon Reeve Musk - Tesla, Inc. Well, I just said it's in China. /.../ Robin Ren - Tesla, Inc. We are in good discussion with the government, so we'll announce something (01:04:34). Elon Reeve Musk - Tesla, Inc. Okay. So Robin Ren is here with me. Robin is managing worldwide sales for Tesla right now. He was born and raised in Shanghai. (01:04:54) But we'll talk more about – I think in the next earnings call or next – we'll have a lot more to say about that in the future." Source: https://seekingalpha.com/article/4169027-tesla-tsla-q1-2018-results-earnings-call-transcript?part=single

The PRC have apparently lifted the requirement for a Chinese partner, but one hasn't read the full reports, so there may be conditions that effectively negate the repeal.  In any case, there doesn't seem to be any hot action on this front.  That, of course, doesn't prevent The Announcements Company delivering itself of an announcement, which seems to be all it would take to make this a Yes.  Tesla is not likely to make such an announcement without fist getting the okey-dokey from the Chinese government, but with Tesla one never knows.

I'm wiggling my numbers more towards an outright No.   I started thinking about it and I remembered something from grad school:  Registered Capital.   In a super condensed explanation; you get a tax holiday when you send your capital over for the first time as a WFOE.  In Tesla's case, this would be all the capital required to secure the permits, build your factory, purchase all your raw materials, set up your distribution network (or set up a dealership network) and meet payroll for all senior management, factory workers and sales force until you are "self sufficient".   If you do not send enough and need more capital sent from the parent company, you're taxed at a rate of 25% on that transfer - which can take days/weeks to clear through the Bank of China.   They aren't just sending over money for the plant,  The problem is; Tesla doesn't have that much latitude with it's US capital right now, so it would behoove them to send over a generous amount and save the remainder for extraordinary expenses rather than miss their budget target and lose 25% on a $1B transfer.   In 2016, China based LeEco invested $1.8B in a hybrid auto plant, so figure with inflation and Tesla's Apple'esque passion for the state of the art, assume Tesla will need about $2.2B just for the plant, then maybe another $1.5B for all the other expenses listed above, plus 15% just to be safe, and you're looking at about ~$4.3B in upfront investment.... All while they're blowing through $1B per quarter stateside and still not "self sufficient".    https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-11-21/tesla-is-blowing-through-8-000-every-minute-amid-model-3-woes

Came across this article from Nov 2 2017 (https://www.wsj.com/articles/tesla-reveals-time-frame-for-china-factory-1509599003):  "Tesla Inc. TSLA -3.28% indicated Wednesday that it plans to make cars and sport-utility vehicles in China in about three years as part of a bet to make the pricey electric vehicles more appealing to local buyers. Chief Executive Elon Musk laid out the timeline Wednesday during a conference call with analysts, saying he doesn’t expect significant investment in a China factory until 2019. The Silicon Valley auto maker has been vague about its efforts to set up a factory in the Middle Kingdom beyond a statement that it was exploring the possibility with the city of Shanghai and aimed to announce its plans by year’s end. The Wall Street Journal reported last month that the car maker had reached an agreement to set up its own manufacturing facility in the city’s free-trade zone. Such an agreement would be a milestone for a U.S. company operating in China, giving Tesla a first-of-its kind arrangement and a way around forming a partnership with a local company. /.../ Even with tariffs that make the least-costly Model S roughly 50% more expensive in China than in the U.S., Tesla’s sales in the country have surged in recent years. The auto maker’s revenue in China rose to more than $1 billion last year, from $319 million in 2015, representing about 15% of total revenue and making the country Tesla’s second-largest market." Implications: Tesla aimed to make an announcement by end of 2017. I suppose they didn't do because the negotiations stalled over the Joint Venture disagreement (I emphasize that this is just speculating). Now that is out of the way (see my previous comment: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/723988), so we could see an announcement of some sort in the not too distant future.  No significant investment expected until 2019. This to some extent separates in time the factory from Tesla's current problems. This time window could allow them to announce the Chinese factory with the hopes that a production ramp up at the Fremont factory will solve their cash flow problems and encourage investors to shell over in 2019 for a China factory. This is all assuming that they would announce the factory so much earlier than the actual investment and construction, which is not unlike Tesla I suppose. Sales of Teslas in China are not to be underestimated as a source of revenue. China's middle class is growing and I think many would enjoy the cachet of driving an American car bursting with modern technology and environmental credentials, especially in zones where internal combustion engines are not allowed due to pollution controls. There is a significant willingness to pay for foreign luxury cars it seems based on my limited knowledge (see e.g. https://asia.nikkei.com/Business/Business-Trends/Chinese-buyers-spur-rise-in-global-luxury-car-sales).

Only 40 days left on question. Presumably, none of Tesla's announcements up to this point have resolved the question. China has reduced import tariffs on cars. If I were Musk, this might make a Chinese factory less urgent, as Teslas are not ideal for that market anyway. I assume he is planning on selling primarily the Model 3 in China. If he could get production on Model 3 up to pace, he could test the market in China with the lower tariffs. Of course, Musk didn't get where he is by being cautious. But does any Tesla car have what it takes to sell in large numbers in China? Seems to me the Chinese want tiny city cars. Are there enough Chinese who want compact or mid-size to justify the trouble of a factory there? Does the sale of 5% to Tencent lock Tesla into a joint venture?  Time is running short on this question.

'Relaxing' of JV rules is desperation and too late anyways, state-owned/approved factories are established.  Tesla won't be able to compete. Risks of disruption by CCP is just too high. Anything from hassling or harrassment, minor sabotage or wrongful arrests and extortion. Threatened with trumped up charges. Conviction rates of 99.9% is dangerous and has a big chilling effect.  Why would Elon bother? Reputational risks, more travel to polluted China, lose IP and tarnish the luxury label.  History of Western corporate carcasses litters financial district of Shanghai (not suggesting Tesla would die there, but there are so many bad deals and insurmountable losses).  Consensus of 16 to 20% suggests people are overreacting to Model 3 woes, and underestimating tenacity of Musk. Conveniently forgetting Model X and S are going along fine. And the tax breaks and great workforce in US.

Going 50/50 now. 50% because China just lifted the requirement of 50/50 ownership; the other 50% of nothing happens because of Tesla's financial and production problems. A shoutout to @Chrisp for this info at http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/724274, http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/724256,  and http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/724411

There are some leaked emails (see Forbes) that suggest (at least to me) that Tesla is caught between failure to hit manufacturing  targets and running out of cash. It seems to have decided to go for increasing manufacturing in what appears to be using an expensive (and possibly unsustainable) 24/7 running of its production line. To me it looks like the aim would be to hit the production target for a few weeks (to show it can be done) and then raise more cash to enable it to upgrade the line to allow it to hit the production target permanently. I would suggest that Tesla needs to get its production up and start making a profit before every major auto maker in the world swamps Tesla's sector of the market. Maybe Tesla can compete in the US, but in most of the world an electric car with a premium brand name, is an electric car with a premium brand name, and most premium brands are close to bringing out their own electric cars.

The language on the "chinese partner" is troubling. 
Tesla has a partner; and that partner builds its autonomous driving units.  Does that make it an automotive partner?    Clarification needed.  For the time being, as I regard tencent has a critical partner due to: a). coding
b).  autonomous driving 
c).  Capital I'm treating this as  yes, its a chinese partner, even though it isn't a 50:50 partnership.

Like @cdob63 I am skeptical regarding Tesla, but making announcements is what Musk does. A normal company does not keep shutting its production line for 5 days (twice in 3 months) and then while under producing against its stated targets for its main product announces it is going to build a new facility in China, while seemingly lacking the cash to do so. But Musk is great ideas salesman. Maybe he can kill two birds with one stone, get his bedazzled investors to put in more money to fund the dream of a Chinese factory, which might keep his US operation on the road long enough to hit his US sales targets. He might even turn a profit one day.

Further reflecting on the recent news, I am shifting to a likely yes, mostly because an announcement is a relatively low bar to clear. See my earlier comment for details: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/723988
Increasing odds after China JV rules relaxation.

In the news today: China's NDRC announced it would allow foreign electric car companies to set up shop this year without a local partner: https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/17/business/china-auto-electric-cars-joint-venture.html? "The immediate big winner from the decision would be Tesla, which has already negotiated for a site in the Shanghai area to build cars but has been reluctant to accept a joint venture partner. Going into the Chinese market alone would mean that Tesla could keep better control of its technology and retain all the profits. Still, that means Tesla would have to foot the entire investment cost as well, instead of sharing it with a local partner. Other automakers have learned to work with their Chinese partners to smooth over potential political and labor issues and invest in new facilities together." Takeaways: 1) the chance of a joint venture is visually zero now I think given that Tesla wanted independence all along and now it's got it.  2) the chance that this happens within the question's timeframe is now much higher. The joint venture question seemed to be the main reason the negotiations stalled in February (https://www.bloomberg.com/news/videos/2018-02-14/talks-stall-on-tesla-s-plans-to-open-factory-in-china-video) The main uncertainty now is whether it will happen before July 1.  One the pessimistic side, Musk's focus is on the Model 3 production, which Tesla needs to ramp up to stave off cash flow concerns, which earlier this year led to a credit rating downgrade by Moody's (https://www.cnbc.com/2018/03/27/moodys-downgrades-tesla-credit-rating-on-model-3-production-delays.html). A poor rating is a problem for Tesla, which, I assume, would need additional financing for the new factory in China. To secure it, Tesla would have to prove it can churn out cars in its Fremont plant first, I would imagine.  Additionally, there are more questions to be resolved and hoops to be jumped before Tesla can make a credible announcement. In November 2017, Musk said the China plans had a "3 year timeframe" (see Bloomberg link; whether that means factory up and running in 3 years or not is unclear to me). There is the financing question, but here is also a question as to the tariffs Tesla would to paying. President Jinping had announced earlier an intention to lower auto tariffs (https://www.cnbc.com/2018/04/10/gm-tesla-shares-jump-after-chinas-xi-announces-plan-to-lower-car-tariffs.html) but the unresolved trade tensions with the U.S. mean that it's up in the air. However, all it takes to resolve this question is an announcement. Given that the negotiations have been going on for 10 months (Bloomberg link above) and are relatively far along with the NYT saying Tesla "has already negotiated a site", it seems quite possible for this to happen relatively soon. Musk might have an incentive to do it sooner rather than later to distract from the Model 3 production problems and make investors excited about the future of the company again. It fits his pattern of grand announcement making. On the whole, I lean toward "no" due to the short time frame, but I am not very confident.
If I were The Announcements Company I'd suspend the grandiosity and lay low for a while. People are starting, belatedly in my opinion, to  be skeptical.

11 weeks to go. There is a chance it will happen in time but dependent on trade/tariff situation etc.  Prime on “no”until something clears up.
https://cleantechnica.com/2018/04/12/tesla-trump-tariffs-china-holds-the-key/

This is my initial guess. Though this seems more likely than not to happen eventually, I think July is too soon given reports that the negotiations have stalled. The focus at Tesla right now is probably mostly on ramping up Model 3 production. The company's cash flow problems are also a concern. On top of it all the threat of a trade war provides an additional distraction. On the more optimistic side, the decrease in auto tariffs shows tensions may be thawing (https://www.cnbc.com/2018/04/10/gm-tesla-shares-jump-after-chinas-xi-announces-plan-to-lower-car-tariffs.html). But it can also be seen as a negative. From my understanding tariffs are essentially the price companies pay for not partnering with a Chinese company (https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/22/business/tesla-plant-in-china-may-be-a-first.html). The prospect of Musk getting his wish to be independent and paying lower tariffs seems like quite a concession from China.

All it takes is an announcement. This is unofficial but clearest I’ve heard of Tesla intent in China. Could play to Uncle Xi’s trade policies and politics as well.
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-tesla-model-y-exclusive/exclusive-tesla-targets-november-2019-for-start-of-model-y-production-sources-idUSKBN1HI2ZV

- Announcement of lower tariffs makes it more likely Telsa will import cars to China.
The tariff issues and Tesla 3 production problems will need to be resolved before any new ventures by Musk

Let us presume the news is reflecting an actual imminent deal, and not just PR. The question seems (deliberately?) unclear, if "Chinese partner" explicitly means joint venture. I will assume it does not. China's current trade disputes with the US, have a two fold impact. On one hand, it may serve Chinese interests, to craft a deal with Tesla to set a template for new rules for foreign factories in China. Tesla has shared some of its IP already, and may be eager to blaze the trail. On the other hand, if China gives leeway on IP/joint ventures, or any other terms, for some factories, then further negotiation would be expected with others, and with the US administration. This is likely a geopolitical positive, but may have unpredictable, extensive ramifications.
China committed to its own electric car industry. Musk unlikely to cede the kind of control China production would require
it can be dangerous for the company and oot of its focus.
allowing 20% for bin 2 - the tariff war may impact cost and production and a plant in China may solve that.

Relaxed strategic partnerships make it possible but, visionaries lose credibility by chasing low cost production. I'd be very surprised to see Tesla take that leap when half of the allure are is quality fair manufacturing.

With less than 3 months left before the end date, a number of issues would need to be resolved very quickly.  I don't expect so many things to fall into place within the given time-frame. Simultaneously, the noises coming from China regarding their rules requiring partnerships with locals make me think it's almost as likely to come together without a Chinese partner as with, if it comes together at all.

http://www.autonews.com/article/20180313/GLOBAL03/180319908/tesla-shanghai-china-factory-elon-musk-trump
Clearly there is a breakdown between the two side, but also signs they want a deal. The real question is how fast. Which is unlikley before 1JULY18.
current trade wars and general opinion of tesla management on overseas manufacturing.

Might have to announce something. Only getting 200 daily 3s made, but are fighting to 'prove the haters wrong' by going to 300 a day.  Burning through cash at $6,500 a minute and the bond has dropped to 86 cents on the $, with the share price at a low and the shorts at a high of 25%. Not looking good at all.  If they need to borrow more, or when they do it'll have to be over 10%. Could this be the end?
The Announcements Company has been diverted a bit of late, so they probably won't get to this before the closing of this Q.

I have forecast against any Tesla manufacturing in China. I’m not changing yet, but wondering about impact of China scooping up most of the cobalt...

Tesla is having problems with domestic production and will not look to add production overseas

Tesla shareholders' sentiment, as reflected by the $55bn payout confidence vote to Musk, I believe, reflects a wide support, in light of his 13 March announcements and against latest US tariff wars pronouncements.

Musk is ambitious and will likely succeed in negotiatons that favorably support Tesla's (and ultimately other US EV manufaturers) building a factory in China however, unlikely to be announced in the next 3 months.   The quote below, from an article dated 13Mar2018, illustrates 2 huge hurdles that contradict the entrepreneurial capitalism that Elon Musk represents. “No US auto company is allowed to own even 50% of their own factory in China, but there are five 100% China-owned EV auto companies in the US. I am against import duties in general, but the current rules make things very difficult. It’s like competing in an Olympic race wearing lead shoes.” -Elon Musk (https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-china-factory-update-shanghai-officials/)

Conflicting reports on how negotiations are going: https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-china-factory-update-shanghai-officials/ Musk tweet-lobbying: http://www.scmp.com/business/china-business/article/2136467/musk-lobbies-trump-prod-china-over-auto-trade-practises I don't see a definitive announcement about a factory soon. Negotiations are rocky. If the non-specific announcement that Tesla already made does not count, we're probably not going to get something more concrete in the next 3 months. Always possibility of a breakthrough in the negotiations though.

Based on March 2017 TIMEs article US OEMS make on average 65% of their vehicles overseas.  So baseline would be 65% chance that Tesla will begin producing overseas and 45% chance that they will not. However both Yes options pos significant risk or lose.  Things might look better if China relaxed its laws requiring a JV, however, the farther we move into 2018 the less likely these changes seem. This almost doubles my no forecast.

Tesla should focus on getting there existing factory working before announcing others. The market would not look favorably on a decision to build another plant at this time. They have lost many key execs that would be needed to make a deal in China - no  bandwidth for this at this time.

I know that lots of people think Tesla is a uniquely wonderful company, but looking at the data I see a company that loses money, that has terrible quality control problems, can't seem to actually make many cars. I read about lots of other companies that actually manage to make cars, that have good QC, that make profits and have lots of electric models in the pipeline. Some of them actually make more electric cars than Tesla. Unless Tesla get their act together in the next few months they will be toast.

Tesla as a technology company has remained super-secretive about its technology and manufacturing processes. Due to the patent infringement as well as corporate espionage concerns surrounding China, Tesla might not want to shift its manufacturing to China. However, with China emerging as a key destination for E-vehicles, if the Chinese Govt makes local manufacturing a mandatory clause for foreign players, Tesla might want to build a factory in China.
Tough call. Partnerships are great, but location and strategy are also key.

The Chinese are not going to allow wholly owned foreign manufacturing in the foreseeable future. The Trump presidency makes this even more unlikely.  Elon Musk is a driven man. Now the major unknowns are not whether Tesla worried about IP or technology leaking. BMW had built its most sophisticated plant in Shenyang including the engine production and many other traditional car company do the same. It is also not Tesla doesn't like Chinese auto market which is the largest market so far and growing ferociously especially in electric vehicles. Major cities has put a bidding or lottery policy to limit the total number of gasoline cars and those cars also have been limited to go on roads during certain period of rush ours. But EV car can be bought and used without such limitation. 
The Chinese government put developing EV car as its national strategy and many local companies have put a lot of effort on the section. Even internet giants have invest many new startups and many of those companies get a lot of inspiration from Tesla. Tencent invest Nio and Alibaba invest Xpeng. Not to mention BYD and many other power competitors already sell EV cars in large quantities. If Tesla fail to  introduce their entry level car to Chinese market on time, it will miss huge opportunity. So I believe Tesla has strong incentive to get this done ASAP.
Back to Tesla, the execution track record is not good. It faced a lot of problem to launch mass production cars and for Musk, he is too busy with many other "important" things so he might not fully involved and push the team to accomplish the target. So I gave -20% for NO.

Check the recent opened the Starbucks Wonderland in Shanghai, that show tremendous support from local government. With mixed information i'll give another -5% NO.

There are several issues to consider; what counts as a Chinese partner? How firm does the announcement need to be? Would any direct investment in a Tesla Chinese car plant count as a "partner"? What is the difference between a "partner" and an "investor"? Presumably a "partner" would be an entity that played an active role in the Tesla China manufacturing business while an "investor" would supply money but would play a passive role.  Would an announcement that "we plan to build a Chinese factory to make cars in three years, no site has been identified, we have not yet decided its capacity" count? So does the announcement need to be specific about when, where, what, budget, capacity etc.?  Tesla seems to have its hands full getting its US manufacturing plant up to speed. A normal company would probably want to sort this out before announcing where it was going next, but Tesla is not a normal company. Even so it seems likely that Tesla's management would be fully engaged with sorting out US problems for the moment which might delay any further announcements about China for a while (a month? 6 months?) There are also possible political considerations. What would Trump do if Tesla did say it was manufacturing in China? Trump would presumably think that as a US company (albeit one run by an immigrant) should be making products in the US and exporting them to China (to Make America Great Again). As Climate Change is "Fake News" and electric cars are part of the plot by the global liberal elite to harm the US who knows what Trump might do to try and make life difficult for Tesla if they were compounding their undermining of the American Way of Life by planning a Chinese factory? (I am not sure where immigrants from South Africa stand on the spectrum between S***holes and Norway, maybe it depends on what the immigrant looks like?)

The WSJ reports that Tesla has struck a deal to open manufacutring plants in the Shanghai Free Zone, where Chinese partnership rules are less strict. Manufacturing without a Chinese partner allows Tesla to remain in control of their production, quality and trade secrets. This allows Tesla to build their luxury model cars at a lower cost for the Chinese and other Asian markets. Manufacturing with a Chinese partner would allow Tesla to sell to the Chinese market with the tarrifs. It could also be a trial run for future production of their lower end models. I am unsure of Tesla has any plans to produce lower end models. There's a possibility of a no depending on the terms of the deal that is signed. The deal might also be disrupted if part of the terms for approval would require giving certain Chinese officials financial incentives.

This article implies that Tesla will manufacture cars in Shanghai, as opposed to parts, but, as the deal has not been worked out yet, that's not certain. https://www.wsj.com/articles/tesla-strikes-deal-with-shanghai-to-build-factory-in-china-1508670181?mg=prod/accounts-wsj
Updating my prediction based on the following news: https://www.theverge.com/2017/10/22/16516064/tesla-reached-deal-factory-china-shanghai-electric-vehicles-cars
Based on publicly available news reports and research into China's history with Automotive company partnerships.
I guess they will only manufacture Parts in China with a Chinese Partner! And I think that will be batterys.

Key Factors:
1. Tesla is heavily indebted, running negative cashflow and not profitable currently - further expansion of investments is at risk if there is any loss of confidence by the market in the stock. High risk of a negative correction with any wider macro factors. This lowers the chances of manufacturing in China.
2. Elon Musk is a promotional CEO that regularly announces exciting initiatives / deals to propagate continued interest in the stock and keep the multiple high. This increases the chance of an announcement, however may not result in the actual construction of a manufacturing site. Given the question asks for an announcement only, I'd increase the chance based on this.
3. The base rate for Chinese regulatory reform is low due to the protection of SOE's and vested interests - this lowers the chance of manufacturing without a partner.
4. Recent talk of reform mitigates point 3. above somewhat and makes it more likely.
5. The base rate for automakers producing in China currently is higher for with a partner as that is the current regulatory environment.
Tesla has to get its costs down, and unfortunately, this is an "easy" way to do it.

China is apparently considering relaxing their rule that foreign automakers must operate in joint ventures to manufacture cars in China. I think this is more likely to happen than not before 1 June, and if so, I think Tesla would announce quickly. And, given the trouble Tesla has had in ramping up production in their USA production, I find it unlikely that they would pursue a joint venture in the near term.
Tesla wants to participate in growing markets and sees its chances in US threatened

Tesla is partnering with Toyota and Mercedes and could expand manufacturing via existing carmakers in different parts of the world and because tensions with China will affect Panasonic, Teslas Japanese battery partner. Also China is likely to be a major competitor to Tesla's manufacturing plans. The Chinese see manufacturing as their own core strength and China wants to own brand more of its manufactured products.

It seems wildly unlikely that the PRC would let this sort of manufacturing go on without a local partner.  In other news, the high P on this is because Tesla need only announce this, not meet any deadline for actual changes in the physical universe.  As we all know, Tesla's reputation is, shall we say, spotty in the matter of of meeting deadlines.  Big announcements, on the other hand, contitute their main line of business.
